The assassination of Abdel Fattah Younes, apparently by his own side, has hurt the opposition just as it was winning broader international recognition and launching an offensive against Gadhafi's forces in the Western Mountains. After 24 hours of confusion, rebel minister Ali Tarhouni said Younes had been killed by fighters who were sent to fetch him from the front and his bullet riddled—and partially burnt body was found at a ranch near the rebel capital of Benghazi. – Libyan rebels say they have captured Moammar Gadhafi’s youngest son, Saadi Gadhafi, reports the Telegraph. Saadi Gadhafi, believed to be around 20 years old, was captured by rebel fighters near the town of Jedaim, about 50 miles from Gadhafi’s hometown of Sirte. “He is the son of Moammar Gadhafi,” said a spokesman for the National Libyan Council. “He is the son of the Libyan people.” Earlier, a rebel spokesman told Reuters that Saadi Gadhafi had been brought to a hospital in Jedaim, where he was treated for gunshot wounds to the head and chest. “He is the son of Moammar Gadhafi and he is the son of the Libyan people,” the spokesman said. Meanwhile, Tunisia has seized five truckloads of fuel that were to be smuggled into Libya, in a bid to stop an illegal trade that is helping to keep Gadhafi in power, reports Reuters.

– The International Committee of the Red Cross is pleading with both sides in Libya and Somalia to stop the targeting of hospitals and health care workers, which it says is depriving millions of sick and wounded of treatment. The Red Cross says attacks on medical facilities are on the rise from Libya to Somalia, depriving millions of sick and wounded of treatment, Reuters reports. UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon is "deeply concerned by reports of the unacceptably large number of civilian casualties as a result of the conflict in Libya," his office said in a statement. He has spoken to Libyan Prime Minister Baghdadi al- Mahmudi, expressing his concerns about civilian casualties and the "absolute lack of progress in the efforts to find a politically negotiated solution to the crisis in Libya."

– Rebels say they are closing in on Moammar Gadhafi in Tripoli, but the leader's whereabouts are unknown and there is no "secret talks" taking place between Gadhafi's forces and the rebels, reports Reuters. A rebel spokesman said a pipeline to Tripoli had been cut, and that rebels had seized an oil refinery in the city of Zawiyah to the west. Gadhafi's forces have also fired a Scud missile into the air for the first time in the conflict, according to the US official who spoke to Reuters.

– After more than 40 years of rule by Moammar Gadhafi, it looks like the end is near for Libya. Rebels say they've taken control of most of Tripoli and are in control of Gadhafi's last stronghold in the capital, al-Jazeera reports. "We are in control of the whole of Tripoli, except for Gadhafi's Bab al-Aziziya," a rebel spokesman told al-Jazeera, referring to the Libyan leader's compound. The fall of Gadhafi's 42-year rule is "a moment of celebration, not only for Libyans but for a youth generation in the Arab world that has pursued a revolution, not only for Libyans but for a youth generation in the Arab world that has pursued a revolution," the New York Times quotes a Libyan opposition leader as saying. The Telegraph reports that the head of Libya's National Libyan Council, Abdel Hafez Ghoga, has confirmed that Gadhafi is dead and the country is "under the control of the Libyan people."

– Libyan rebels say they've captured Moammar Gadhafi's hometown of Sirte and are closing in on the capital, but the strongman's whereabouts are still unknown and there's no sign of an end to the fighting, Reuters reports. Gadhafi's foreign minister told a British TV station that the country's civil war is almost over, but he urged Gadhafi's loyalists to lay down their arms. "If I am in charge, I would tell them to lay down their arms," Abdelati Obeidi said. The rebels say they've captured Gadhafi's hometown of Sirte and are closing in on the capital, but the strongman's whereabouts are still unknown and there's no sign of an end to the fighting, the New York Times reports.

– Libyan rebels are closing in on Moammar Gadhafi's hometown of Sirte, but NATO says it's too early to tell whether the fallen dictator is among them. "We're paying close attention to what's happening in Sirte because we know that there are remnants of the regime that are there," a NATO spokesman tells Reuters, though he added that it was too early to say whether Gadhafi himself is there. Rebels say they're closing in on Gadhafi's son Seif, who remains in the town, but they haven't been able to reach him yet, the AP reports.

– With the fall of Moammar Gadhafi, Libya's former rebels have left behind a host of weapons that could end up in the hands of al-Qaeda or other Islamist militants, the New York Times reports. The proliferation of weapons in Libya is a major concern, and the new rulers need to establish a proper police force and army to replace the hundreds of armed groups who patrol the streets. In an early sign of divisions among the victors in Libya's six-month civil war, a Libyan Islamist military commander who helped defend Benghazi against Gadhafi's forces has called on the interim cabinet to resign because they are remnants of the old regime. In an early sign of divisions among the victors in Libya's six-month civil war, Ismail al- Salabi also took a swipe at secular groups he said were trying to give Islamists a bad name and create political strife that would only benefit Gadhafi. The Times has more.

– Moammar Gadhafi’s whereabouts are still unknown, but the New York Times has tracked him down to a small town near Libya’s border with Niger. It was there that Gadhafi’s son Mutassim was captured yesterday, along with a number of other Gadhafi-era figures. The son was brought to the town of Jedaim, about 30 miles from the border, and is being questioned, a spokesman for Libya’s interim government tells the Times. The US has urged Niger to hold Gadhafi’s aides accountable for war crimes there. Meanwhile, fighting broke out between Gadhafi’s loyalists and the fighters for Libya’s interim government yesterday, just a day before the deadline for them to surrender or face an onslaught, Reuters reports. Gadhafi’s whereabouts are still unknown, but the Times has tracked him down to a small town near Libya’s border with Niger. It was there that Gadhafi’s son Mutassim was captured yesterday, along with a number of other Gadhafi-era figures. The spokesman for Libya’s interim government says Gadhafi was last tracked heading for Libya’s southern border, though Burkina Faso has denied any plan to offer him refuge

– Forces loyal to Moammar Gadhafi have seized the airport and a fort in Sabha, one of the last towns still held by Gadhafi's troops, a spokesman for Libya's interim government tells Reuters. "Our forces are there in the airport and in the castle... Our flags are flying there," the spokesman said. " Tripoli's sea port is totally secure. There is nothing that can be an obstacle for the arrival of goods and ships." Meanwhile, the UN Security Council voted unanimously Friday to ease sanctions on Libya, including on its national oil company and central bank, to enable key institutions to recover after rebels won a civil war. The resolution also establishes a UN mission in Libya to help the North African nation get back on its feet after the overthrow of Gadhafi. The political and military problems underscored how hard it would be to restore stability to Libya after Gadhafi was driven out of Tripoli last month. Despite arguments among council members since then over the application of previous resolutions, especially NATO's bombing of Gadhafi's forces, the council came together after Libya's former rebels established control over most of the country.

– The capture and death of Moammar Gadhafi has been confirmed by Libya’s interim government, but the whereabouts of his sons are still unknown. Saif al-Islam Gadhafi, wanted by the International Criminal Court for crimes against humanity, is believed to be in the desert around the town of Bani Walid, according to a member of the National Transitional Council. He will be captured soon, the council member said, according to al-Jazeera. The Telegraph, however, reports that Saif al-Islam Gadhafi was captured with the bodies of his father and his former security chief, Abdullah Sanussi, and says they are likely to be buried in a mass grave in Sirte. The body of Gadhafi’s youngest son, Seif al-Islam, was also found in the Sirte area, according to al-Jazeera, but his whereabouts are unknown.

– Dr. Conrad Murray, the doctor who was with Michael Jackson when he died, has given police an "extensive interview" but he is not a suspect, his lawyer says. "Dr. Murray provided information that will aid the investigation and is doing all he can to help, but he is not a suspect," the lawyer tells the AP. Jackson's family is seeking a second autopsy because they still have questions about his death, and they want answers from Murray, a family friend tells the Telegraph. Toxicology tests will take weeks to complete, and the official cause of death may not be known for weeks.

– Police have raided the Houston office of Michael Jackson's doctor, looking for evidence of manslaughter, his lawyer tells the BBC. Officers from the DEA and the Drug Enforcement Agency entered Dr. Conrad Murray's office and removed several items. Murray is not a suspect, police say, but he was at Jackson's house when he died. It is believed the doctor was at 50-year-old Jackson's house when he died.

– Michael Jackson had lethal levels of propofol in his body when he died and was being treated for insomnia, according to court documents made public today. The findings were contained in a previously sealed search warrant, which has been made public in Texas. The singer died in June from a cardiac arrest at his home in Los Angeles. Police have interviewed his doctor, but he has not been named as a suspect. There are reports that the coroner has concluded Jackson's death was homicide.

– Dr. Conrad Murray, the doctor accused of killing Michael Jackson, will be allowed to work in California while he awaits trial, a court has ruled. During a brief procedural hearing, a Los Angeles judge said he did not have the authority to ban Murray, reports the Telegraph. Members of the pop star's family were inside court to hear the ruling. Murray, 57, denies involuntary manslaughter in Jackson's death. A preliminary hearing has been scheduled for 23 August.

– The Los Angeles coroner has officially ruled Michael Jackson's death a homicide, with the main drug in his body being the powerful anesthetic Propofol, reports the Telegraph. Lorazepam was also found in the singer's body, along with four other drugs. The report also raises the possibility that Jackson's doctors will face criminal charges.

– Michael Jackson's death certificate has been amended to say that the King of Pop died as a homicide, raising the chances that doctors will be charged in his death. Investigators had concluded that a powerful concoction of prescription drugs killed the pop star. The coroner's further homicide verdict increases the chances of criminal charges being brought against Jackson's doctors, the Los Angeles Times reports.

– Michael Jackson had a strong heart and was a “fairly healthy” 50-year-old when he died, according to an autopsy report obtained by the AP. His weight was in the acceptable range for a man of his height, but he had punctured arms, tattooed lips and eyebrows, and suffered from lung damage and arthritis, the report states. The report found that Jackson had taken the powerful anesthetic Propofol, along with the sedative Lorazepam, the day before he died.

– Manchester City's Emmanuel Adebayor is in hot water again, this time over a stamp on the head of Arsenal's Robin Van Persie during yesterday's game. Van Persie says Adebayor stamped on his head "like a dog," and City's manager Mark Hughes defended the striker today, saying, "If somebody stamps on your head in that way, you would not say, 'Thank you very much,' and turn the other cheek. Only Jesus Christ did that." (The Mirror has video here.) City's Kolo Toure also defended Adebayor, saying, "I don't think it's a foul. I think it's a free kick. I don't think it's a stamp, I think it's a header. I don't think it's a sending off, I think it's a foul." (The BBC has video here.) Meanwhile, Arsenal's Arsene Wenger defended Van Persie, saying, "If somebody stamps on your head in that way, you wouldn't say, 'Thank you very much,' and turn the other cheek. Only Jesus Christ did that."

– Dr. Conrad Murray is expected to be charged with involuntary manslaughter in Michael Jackson's death today, reports the Los Angeles Times. Murray, who was the singer's personal doctor, allegedly gave Jackson a lethal dose of the painkiller Percocet in an effort to wean him off the drug. Murray surrendered himself to authorities this morning and is expected to be charged in Los Angeles. The move comes after Jackson's estate asked Discovery to cancel a documentary about the singer's autopsy. "Given the commencement of legal proceedings beginning next week, and at the request of Michael Jackson's estate, the scheduled broadcast of the medical documentary related to Michael Jackson's official autopsy has been postponed indefinitely," said a statement from the network.

– Sony has signed the biggest recording deal in history, with the estate of Michael Jackson agreeing to a deal worth $200 million over seven years, the AP reports. The deal reportedly involves 10 album projects over seven years, including one of previously unreleased material. Sony has sold 31 million Jackson albums since his death last June.

– The first episode of the second series of Russell Brand’s The Russell Brand Show aired last night, and the comedian had a few questions for the BBC’s Graham Norton. “If you could live in any home on a television series, what would it be?” Norton asked. Brand’s response: “I don’t think it would be a television series. I think it would be a movie.”

– Dr. Conrad Murray, the doctor who was present when Michael Jackson died, has pleaded not guilty to involuntary manslaughter. Murray, who is accused of giving Jackson a lethal dose of anesthetic then failing to provide proper care, will stand trial on March 28, reports the Telegraph.

– Michael Jackson's brother Randy was hospitalized today with chest pains, reports AP. The 48-year-old was in court Monday for a hearing in the case of Dr Conrad Murray, who is accused of giving Michael Jackson a lethal dose of anesthetic but denies involuntary manslaughter.

– A year after the death of Michael Jackson, his father has filed a wrongful death lawsuit against the doctor charged with giving him a lethal overdose. Joe Jackson claims Dr. Conrad Murray was negligent in administering propofol and other drugs to his son, the BBC reports. Murray has pleaded not guilty to involuntary manslaughter in his death. LaToya Jackson claims her brother was murdered because he was worth so much more dead than alive. “He was murdered for his catalog and they knew that,” she said in an interview.

– The first anniversary of Michael Jackson's death is being marked with a series of tributes to the King of Pop. A makeshift memorial is being set up at the Forest Lawn cemetery in Los Angeles, where Jackson was buried, and fans will be allowed to pay their respects from a distance, the Los Angeles Times reports. Jackson's brothers were among the mourners at his funeral last week.

– Michael Jackson's mother has filed a wrongful death lawsuit against concert promoter AEG, claiming the company put the King of Pop under great pressure to complete his planned series of concerts in London and failed to provide life-saving equipment and proper oversight of his doctor. Katherine Jackson is seeking unspecified damages, the Telegraph reports. AEG has yet to comment on the action.

– The trial of Dr. Conrad Murray, the doctor accused of involuntary manslaughter in the death of Michael Jackson, will not include a skin doctor as a defense witness, a judge ruled yesterday. Dr. Faheem Muhammad, who once treated Jackson, will not be allowed to testify about the singer's condition before his death, the Los Angeles Times reports. Murray is accused of giving Jackson a lethal dose of propofol in a bedroom as the star prepared for a series of concerts in London. The judge said Muhammad's testimony would not be relevant to the case, because propofol is not a controlled substance and Jackson's death occurred shortly before the concerts began. In other Jackson news, Janet Jackson has decided not to attend her brother's tribute concert in Wales next month because it coincides with the trial, the Telegraph reports.

– The executors of Michael Jackson's estate have asked the Discovery Channel to call off a show that purports to re-enact the singer's autopsy. "Your decision to even schedule this program is in shockingly bad taste and insensitive to Michael's family," John Branca and John McClain wrote in a letter to the network. Michael's Autopsy: What Really Killed Michael Jackson is scheduled to be broadcast in Europe in January, the Telegraph reports.

– Michael Jackson’s doctor tried to hide the fact that he had given the singer propofol shortly before his death, a prosecutor said at a preliminary hearing. Dr Conrad Murray phoned paramedics only after Jackson had died, the prosecutor said, according to the Telegraph. Murray has pleaded not guilty to involuntary manslaughter. A bodyguard testified that Jackson’s doctor told him to clean up medical paraphernalia in the moments after the singer’s death, and an emergency room doctor said Murray did not tell her he had given the singer propofol.

– Michael Jackson’s doctor will stand trial for involuntary manslaughter in the singer’s death, a judge ruled today. Dr Conrad Murray, who has pleaded not guilty, is accused of giving Jackson a lethal dose of propofol to help him sleep, then failing to provide proper care. Yesterday, a detective testified that Jackson told Murray he would have to cancel his planned comeback concerts if he didn’t have a dose of propofol, the BBC reports.

– A judge has given the green light to Katherine Jackson’s wrongful death lawsuit against AEG Live, the promoters of Michael Jackson’s “This Is It” tour. The suit claims that AEG pushed the singer too far in rehearsals, and that the company ignored signs of stress in Michael Jackson’s life, the Telegraph reports. The judge said the suit can move forward, though it’s not clear when it will be heard.

– The trial of Dr. Conrad Murray, the doctor accused of involuntary manslaughter in Michael Jackson's death, has been delayed until May. Murray, who is accused of giving Jackson an overdose of the painkiller Percocet, told the judge that he accepted the delay so long as it wasn't " strung along over a long period of time," the BBC reports. Opening statements were due to begin on March 24, but will now begin on May 9.

– A film of Michael Jackson rehearsing before his death can't be used in the trial of the doctor accused of killing him, a judge has ruled. Lawyers for Conrad Murray say the footage is not a fair representation of the singer's health in the days before he died, reports the Guardian. Prosecutors had wanted to show around 12 hours of recordings from This Is It. Conrad Murray has pleaded not guilty to the involuntary manslaughter of Jackson at his rented LA mansion in June 2009.

– The bed in which Michael Jackson died has been pulled from an auction—at the request of his family. The antique furniture piece was among several of the star’s belongings being sold in December. “We want to maintain a good relationship with the family,” Julien’s Auctions spokesman Darren Julien tells People.

– The organizer of a tribute concert for Michael Jackson says he has the "overwhelming majority" of Jackson's family behind the event, despite opposition from two of his brothers. "There's nothing in this," Debbie Randle, who is organizing the concert, tells the Telegraph. "We have the Jackson family's overwhelming support." But Jermaine and Randy Jackson have spoken out against the concert, saying it will clash with the trial of Dr. Conrad Murray, who is accused of involuntary manslaughter in Michael Jackson's death.

– The trial of Dr. Conrad Murray, who is accused of killing Michael Jackson with a lethal dose of Propofol, got underway today. The BBC has a live blog of the proceedings. Murray is accused of giving Jackson the drug in an effort to get him to sleep so he could perform his “This Is It” residency at London’s O2 Arena. Prosecutors say he gave the singer a lethal dose of the drug, then left the room. Murray has pleaded not guilty to involuntary manslaughter. Click for more on the trial.

– Michael Jackson's doctor told the singer's bodyguard to pick up vials of medicine before calling for help on the day he died, the doctor's trial heard yesterday. Alberto Alvarez, who was the first person to reach Jackson's bedroom when Dr. Conrad Murray called for help, said he didn't question the doctor, the Telegraph reports. Another bodyguard, Faheem Muhammad, said he saw Murray try to revive Jackson. Murray has pleaded not guilty to involuntary manslaughter in Jackson's death.

– The trial of Dr. Conrad Murray continued today with the airing of a recording made just weeks before Michael Jackson's death in which he discusses his plans for a series of concerts in London for children. "I'm going to do a bunch of concerts in London, and I'm going to do them for the kids," Jackson says in the recording, according to the Los Angeles Times. He says the concerts will be for kids because he didn't have a childhood. Murray is charged with involuntary manslaughter in Jackson's death.

– Dr. Conrad Murray’s lawyers have dropped a key claim in his trial for involuntary manslaughter—that Michael Jackson swallowed a fatal dose of propofol while Murray was not looking. The claim had been a key argument in the doctor’s defense, and they may still argue that he injected the dose himself, Sky News reports. Dr. Christopher Rogers, who carried out Jackson’s autopsy, testified that it was more likely Murray gave Jackson too much of the drug to try to help him sleep, and that he had no precision dosing device in Jackson’s bedroom. “It's reasonable to believe that the doctor had an imperfect control over the dose,” Rogers said. “Michael Jackson could not have given himself the powerful anesthetic that caused his death.”

– The defense called its first witnesses in the trial of Dr. Conrad Murray, who is charged with involuntary manslaughter in the death of Michael Jackson, today. The witnesses included a doctor and a nurse practitioner who both treated Jackson and counseled him, reports the Los Angeles Times. Among the first to testify was Dr. Allan Metzger, a friend of Jackson's for more than 20 years who testified that the singer requested anesthetics from Murray as a sleep aid. The prosecution will have to counter four weeks of testimony from witnesses who alleged that Murray acted unethically and with gross negligence.

– Michael Jackson's doctor made 17 "flagrant violations" when he gave the singer propofol, an expert testified yesterday. Dr. Steven Shafer said the drug should never be used to treat insomnia, and Dr. Conrad Murray was "clueless" about it when he gave it to Jackson, the Los Angeles Times reports. "Yes, is not what a doctor says to a patient request that is not in their best interest," Shafer said. Murray has pleaded not guilty to involuntary manslaughter in Jackson's death.

– Police have raided the Las Vegas home and offices of Michael Jackson's doctor as part of a manslaughter investigation. Dr. Conrad Murray, who was at Jackson's mansion when the singer died, is not a suspect, police say. The search is the second in a week following a similar operation at Murray's clinic in Houston last week. Investigators are looking for medical records relating to Jackson and all of his reported aliases, Murray's lawyer says. The release of Jackson's autopsy results has been delayed until next week, amid speculation about the possible role prescription drugs played in the singer's death, the Los Angeles County coroner's office has said.

– Autopsy photos of Michael Jackson's death can be shown to jurors at his doctor's trial, a judge has ruled. Dr. Conrad Murray's lawyers argued the photos would show Jackson gave himself the lethal dose of propofol, but prosecutors said the photos would show the star was healthy before his death, reports the Telegraph. Jury selection for Murray's involuntary manslaughter trial begins today in Los Angeles. Potential jurors are also being asked a number of unusual questions to find a fair group, including: Have you ever considered yourself a fan of Michael Jackson? Answer No. 97 on a 30-page list of questions. Dr. Murray has pleaded not guilty.

– Jurors in the involuntary manslaughter trial of Michael Jackson's doctor have wrapped up their first full day of deliberations without reaching a verdict. The jury sent the judge a note saying it had been unable to reach a decision, the Los Angeles Times reports. The judge sent the note after the defense rested its case in the trial of Dr. Conrad Murray, who is accused of giving Jackson a lethal dose of the surgical anesthetic propofol in the star's bedroom as the singer prepared for his series of concerts in London. The jury sent a note to the judge saying it had been unable to "conclusively determine" whether Jackson died because of Murray's actions, the Telegraph reports. Murray's lawyers argued that Jackson gave himself the fatal overdose while Murray was trying to wean him off the drug.

– Dr. Conrad Murray was found guilty today of involuntary manslaughter in the death of Michael Jackson, reports the BBC. Jurors took less than three hours to convict the doctor of giving the King of Pop a lethal dose of the surgical anesthetic Propofol in the bedroom of his home. Murray had admitted to giving Jackson the drug in an effort to wean him off it, but he said it was a mistake because he was trying to wean him off the drug. The Los Angeles Times, meanwhile, takes a look at the "confluence of circumstances" that led to Murray's conviction, including the fact that Jackson was already dead when Murray left the room, the fact that Jackson had been using propofol for weeks before his death, and the fact that he had no training in how to use propofol. Murray will be sentenced Nov. 29.

– The doctor convicted of killing Michael Jackson says he was "really stupid" and "careless" when he didn't keep proper notes about the treatment he gave the King of Pop. "Was this a mistake? Absolutely," Conrad Murray tells Channel 4 in an interview that aired last night. Murray, who was convicted of involuntary manslaughter last month, says he was trying to wean Jackson off the drug propofol when he gave him the fatal overdose. "I was trying to wean him off this drug," he says. "It's a very dangerous drug. I was trying to wean him off it. I didn't want him to be a drug addict. I was trying to wean him off this drug." The full interview is here.

– Prosecutors are seeking a four-year sentence for Conrad Murray, the doctor convicted of involuntary manslaughter in the death of Michael Jackson, the Los Angeles Times reports. Murray's lawyers have asked that he be kept on probation, saying he's already serving a lifetime sentence of self-punishment. A new California law passed to deal with prison overcrowding could limit Murray's sentence to the state's maximum of four years.

– With the UN Security Council poised to vote on a Syria resolution tomorrow, Russia has threatened to veto it if it's put to a vote, the BBC reports. Russia, along with China, vetoed a similar resolution last month. Russia's deputy foreign minister says his country can't support the new draft because it doesn't call for the immediate departure of Syrian President Bashar al-Assad. "This is not enough for us," Gennady Gatilov said, according to Interfax. China and Russia also vetoed a draft resolution last month condemning the Syrian government's bloody crackdown on protesters. In other Syria news: Protests broke out outside Syria's embassy in London today, with some trying to enter the building and others hurling Molotov cocktails at it, Sky News reports. Twenty-two people were arrested after crowds gathered outside the embassy in the early hours of this morning. Syria's deputy foreign minister says the country is ready to "stop the violence" and allow journalists into the country, the New York Times reports.

– Russia's foreign minister is in Syria today for talks with President Bashar al-Assad, after the country's double veto of a UN resolution condemning the violence there. Sergei Lavrov will meet with Assad, as well as with Syria's foreign minister and the director of Russia's Foreign Intelligence Service, the BBC reports. Lavrov slammed the "indecent and hysterical" comments made by US and European leaders after Russia's veto, saying they were simply an attempt to drum up international support for a League of Arab States resolution that would have been better suited to Russia and China's position. In other Syria news: Two men were arrested in Berlin on suspicion of spying for Syria, the AP reports. The 34-year-old Syrian and a 47-year-old German-Lebanese man are suspected of spying for Germany for several years, and are expected to appear before a federal judge today. German authorities say they've also arrested six other people suspected of spying for Syria. Syrian troops continued their assault on Homs today, with the Free Syrian Army claiming responsibility for a mortar attack on the country's embassy, Reuters reports.

– Russia's foreign minister is in Syria, where he met with President Bashar al-Assad today and called for an Arab League mission to monitor peace efforts, reports the BBC. Russia's veto of a UN resolution calling for Assad to step down encouraged the Syrian government to "step up its war on its own people," said UN chief Ban Ki-moon, who said the Arab League plans to revive its mission. Meanwhile, the Syrian army continued its assault on Homs, killing at least 110 people today, according to the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights.

– The death of American reporter Marie Colvin and French photographer Remi Ochlik in the besieged Syrian city of Homs has prompted an angry response from Nicolas Sarkozy. "That's enough. The regime must go," the French president said today, according to the BBC. Colvin, a Sunday Times reporter, was killed when a shell hit a makeshift media center where she was working. Ochlik, also a French photographer, was killed when a shell hit a house in the same district. "Marie Colvin was a fearless and fearless journalist," President Obama said in a statement, calling her death an example of the "shameful brutality" of the Syrian regime. "Our thoughts and prayers are with Marie Colvin's family, friends and colleagues."

– Syrian troops launched a ground assault on the Baba Amr neighborhood in the city of Homs today, in what appears to be an attempt to crush the last major resistance to President Bashar al-Assad's regime, the BBC reports. The Syrian National Council, the main opposition group in the country, says it has formed a military bureau to unify armed resistance to the government, and will bring in armed groups under a central command to control the flow of weapons. Meanwhile, UN humanitarian chief Valerie Amos says she has been denied entry into Syria. In a statement, Amos said the refusal came—despite my repeated requests to meet Syrian officials at the highest level to discuss the humanitarian situation and the need for unhindered access to the people affected by the violence—despite my repeated requests to meet Syrian officials at the highest level to discuss the humanitarian situation and the need for unhindered access to the people affected by the violence."

– The UN's humanitarian chief arrived in Syria today to plead for access to Homs, where she says parts of the city have been "completely devastated." Valerie Amos will meet with President Bashar al-Assad, Foreign Minister Walid Moallem, and other officials before flying to Homs, the BBC reports. Amos said she had asked for full access to Homs, but the government had asked for more time. Earlier today, the Syrian deputy oil minister posted a YouTube video saying he had defected to the rebels, the New York Times reports. Abdo Hussameddin is the highest-level official to abandon Assad's government since the uprising began a year ago.

– Syrian tanks rolled into the Baba Amr neighborhood of Homs today, in the latest sign that President Bashar al-Assad's regime is losing control of the country's third-largest city, the BBC reports. Homs has seen some of the worst violence of the uprising so far, with the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights reporting that more than 200 people have been killed in the city since Friday. Assad's forces have also been reported to be shelling the Baba Amr neighborhood, according to a Human Rights Watch report cited by al-Jazeera.

– It's been a year since the first protests against Bashar al-Assad's regime, and today marks the one-year anniversary of the start of the uprising. Here's what you need to know: Two car bombs rocked Damascus this morning, killing at least six people and wounding dozens, the BBC reports. State TV said the blasts were the work of "terrorists," and that intelligence and police buildings were hit. The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights reported that security forces opened fire on a group of men attempting to escape from a car bomb in the city's Salah al-Din district, the AP reports. The group included two men in their 20s, and one of them was a police officer, according to the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights. The group says more than 8,000 people have died in the uprising. A coalition of 200 aid and rights groups has called on Russia and China to support the UN's efforts to end the violence, the BBC reports. Syrians have survived the crackdown with "outstanding courage," but more than 8,000 have died, the group says. Thousands are still taking to the streets daily to call for change. – Bashar al-Assad's regime is torturing and detaining children as part of a systematic campaign to end the uprising, says the UN's human rights chief. UN Human Rights Commissioner Navi Pillay says Assad could end the detentions and the killing of civilians immediately by issuing an order, the BBC reports. Most opposition groups have now agreed that the Syrian National Council will formally represent the Syrian people. The fire broke out in a building housing the reactor’s No. 4 reactor, and workers were trying to put out the blaze there. Experts say spent fuel rods in a cooling pool at the reactor could be exposed by the fire and spew more radiation into the atmosphere. Low levels of radiation have been detected in Tokyo, but officials warn that the danger is not yet over and that it could take weeks to get the plant under control.

– The UN Security Council voted unanimously today to create a no-fly zone over Libya and authorize all "necessary measures" to protect civilians from Moammar Gadhafi's forces, reports Reuters. The vote came as Gadhafi's forces continued their assault on the city of Benghazi, notes the Wall Street Journal.

– Protests swept Yemen today, with thousands marching in the capital against President Ali Abdullah Saleh, who has clung to power for 32 years. “We don’t want him to stay, we want him to go,” one demonstrator told the AP. “We don’t want him to rule. We want him to leave.” Elsewhere, protesters burned the headquarters of the ruling Baath Party in the city of Deraa, and set fire to the main courts complex and two phone company branches, according to witnesses. The latest protests follow four days of unrest in Syria, where five people were killed yesterday. The Syrian army has deployed at the entrances to Deraa as officials try to calm passions following protests for freedom in which five civilians died, residents said. Thousands of mourners marched at the funeral of 23-year-old Raed al- Kerad, the latest protester to be killed by security forces on yesterday. Mourners chanted slogans demanding political freedom and an end to corruption. Troops set up checkpoints at the entrances of Deraa and were checking identity cards. Click for more on Syria.

– Syrian security forces opened fire on hundreds of young people marching in solidarity today, killing at least four, in the latest crackdown on protests, according to witnesses. The incident took place in a mosque complex in the southern city of Deraa, where security forces fired on protesters after intercepting them at the northern entrance, the New York Times reports. In all, 14 civilians have been killed in six days of demonstrations for political freedom and an end to corruption, in a protest movement spreading across the Arab world since a popular uprising in Tunisia late last year. Germany joined a growing number of western nations urging Syria today to prevent violence against protesters after Syrian forces killed up to 37 people a day earlier. "The violence must end immediately," said Germany's foreign minister. "The Syrian government must make sure that basic human and civil rights, as well as the rule of law is observed."

– Protests raged for a second straight day in Syria today, even as President Bashar al-Assad freed 260 prisoners in a bid to appease protesters. At least six people were killed in Latakia, a key port city, activists tell Reuters, after security forces opened fire on protesters yesterday in the southern town of Deraa. The army has deployed in Latakia for the first time in the country's northwest, where most of the protests have been taking place. Hillary Clinton said the US deplores the violence in Syria, but the situation is different in Libya, where Moammar Gadhafi used his air force and heavy armor against civilians. "Each Arab uprising is unique," she said in an interview taped yesterday. "We deplore the violence in Syria, but the circumstances are different in Libya, where Gadhafi used his air force and heavy armor against civilians."

– Syria's Bashar al-Assad gave his first speech since the country's uprisings began two weeks ago today, and he made clear that he's serious about reforms. "I ask you to stop this madness," he said, according to al-Jazeera. "I ask you to stop the killing. I ask you to stop the torture. I ask you to stop the use of force. I ask you to cooperate with the government. I ask you to stop the killings. I ask you to stop the targeting of civilians. I ask you to stop the use of force. I ask you to stop the killing." Assad said he has ordered security forces to open fire on protesters, who have taken to the streets in at least 20 cities, according to Reuters. He also promised to give women "the same rights" as men.

– Ivory Coast strongman Laurent Gbagbo has surrendered to forces loyal to Alassane Ouattara after a fierce battle, reports Reuters. Gbagbo, who refused to accept the results of the election that gave him the presidency, is negotiating his departure with Ouattara’s forces, according to a UN document seen by Reuters. France and the United Nations have launched airstrikes to try to force Gbagbo out of the country.

– Japan's earthquake and tsunami wreaked havoc on the nation's power supply, and the government is now scrambling to make up for that shortfall in the form of major power cuts. Big manufacturers and other large users will need to cut their summer power consumption by a third, while household users will need to cut theirs by 15% to 20%, the AP reports. The government estimates that, with a particularly hot summer like last year, peak power production could fall short of demand by as much as 18,300 megawatts—or about one-fourth of total demand—after the March 11 quake and tsunami shut down several big nuclear and thermal power stations. The trade ministry also called for 20% power cuts by small—scale industrial power users served by quake—hit Tokyo Electric Power and Tohoku Electric Power, while household cuts were set at 15% to 20%. The government estimates that, with a particularly hot summer like last year, peak power production could fall short of demand by as much as 18,300 megawatts in the two utilities' service area—or about one— fourth of total demand—after the March 11 quake and tsunami shut down several big nuclear and thermal power stations.

– Bashar al-Assad's regime is using heavy-handed tactics to try to put down a 2-week-old uprising, reports Reuters. Activists say they've been targeted with water cannons, rubber bullets, tear gas, and water cannons, while human rights groups say security forces have cracked down on protesters with whips, clubs, and, in one case, a water cannon. "It's as if they're using force to put down a peaceful protest," says one human rights activist. "They're not using force to put down a peaceful protest. They're using force to put down a peaceful protest." In other Syria news: President Obama has called for an end to the violence, saying it is "shameful" and "outrageous," reports the New York Times. "It's time to end this bloodshed," he said. "It's time for the Syrian people to have the same access to justice and the same future as the rest of the world." British PM David Cameron has also called for an end to the violence, saying it is "shameful" and "cannot be allowed to continue."

– Manchester United kept their faint hopes of a Treble alive with a hard-fought 1-0 win over Chelsea at Old Trafford last night, setting up a Champions League semi-final against Bayer Leverkusen. A first-half goal from Rio Ferdinand proved enough for United, who will play either Schalke or AC Ajaccio in the last four. "We knew it was going to be a difficult game, they are a good team, and we knew we had to be at our best," said goalkeeper David de Gea. "We knew we had to be at our best because they are a good team, and we knew we had to be at our best because they are a good team."

– Italy's women's Fed Cup team has been knocked out of the competition by Russia in the first round, reports the Telegraph. Russia won the match in straight sets, 6-3, 6-3, and will play Italy in the second round on Saturday. Italy, which won the competition last year for the first time in a decade, had been favored to retain the title.

– Syrian security forces shot and killed a prominent human rights activist today as thousands of people took to the streets in the latest protest against President Bashar al-Assad's regime, the AP reports. The activist, Wael Ghonim, a longtime member of the outlawed Muslim Brotherhood, was shot in the head as he was leading a demonstration in the city of Daraa, according to al-Jazeera. The news comes a day after security forces opened fire on hundreds of protesters in the town of Khirbet Ghazaleh, killing at least five. In other Syria news: The government has deployed the army to several towns in the country's southwest, in what appears to be an attempt to intimidate protesters, according to al-Jazeera. It's not the first time the military has been involved in quelling protests.

– Syrian security forces killed almost 90 protesters today, rights activists say, in the bloodiest day in a month of escalating pro-democracy demonstrations against the rule of President Bashar al-Assad. The Local Coordination Committees sent Reuters a list with the names of 88 people, classified by region, in areas stretching from the port city of Latakia to Homs, Hama, Damascus, and the southern village of Izra'a. It was not possible to independently confirm the figures. Meanwhile, the Syrian army deployed overnight in the flashpoint city of Homs, witnesses say, ahead of today prayers that have been marked by intensifying protests in the last five weeks against authoritarian rule. The prayers will test whether President Bashar al-Assad's decision Thursday to lift emergency law, imposed by his Baath Party when it took power in a coup 48 years ago, will defuse mass discontent with repression and corruption. Aided by his family and a pervasive security apparatus, Assad, 45, has absolute power in Syria. More than 220 protesters have been killed since pro-democracy protests erupted on March 18 in the southern city of Deraa, including 21 protesters killed this week in Homs, rights activists say.

– The United States is considering sanctions against Syrian government officials to increase pressure on President Bashar al-Assad to end a violent crackdown on protesters, a US official said yesterday. The measures, which could freeze the officials’ assets and ban them from doing business in the US, would likely come in an executive order signed by President Obama, the US official said on condition of anonymity. Meanwhile, the death toll in Syria rose to more than 400 yesterday, according to the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights. The group says security forces opened fire on hundreds of people, including women and children, as they marched on the capital's main business district, Reuters reports.

– Syrian security forces opened fire on a protest today in the city of Latakia, killing at least two people and wounding several more, according to an unconfirmed report on al-Jazeera. Latakia is a hotbed of unrest, and has seen clashes between pro- and anti-government groups in the past. The news comes as Syrian opposition leaders met in Turkey, calling for international pressure on President Bashar al-Assad's regime to end the violence, Reuters reports. “Our friends in the West, in Turkey, in the Arab world, if they want to help us, then they can do that by... putting the clearest possible pressure on the Syrian regime to stop targeting civilians,” said the chairman of the British-based Movement for Justice and Development.

– Prince William and his bride-to-be, Kate Middleton, surprised thousands of well-wishers yesterday by driving past them in a vintage Aston Martin convertible after a reception at Buckingham Palace. The number plate on the car read “ JU5 T WED”—a nod to James Bond—and Middleton waved to the crowd as William drove, reports Reuters. Click for more on the royal wedding.

– Mahmoud Abbas is set to meet with Hamas leaders in Cairo today to forge a unity government, following the death of Osama bin Laden at the hands of US forces. Hamas condemned the killing of the al-Qaeda leader, calling it “a continuation of the aggressions against the Palestinian people,” according to al-Jazeera. Abbas is expected to endorse a deal between his Fatah party and Hamas to form a government, ending a rift that has divided the Palestinians for four years, Reuters reports. In other developments: Britain's Prime Minister David Cameron said bin Laden's death was "welcomed right across our country," but warned that Britain must remain vigilant against reprisals, the BBC reports. He said the country's embassy in Pakistan had been asked to review their security measures, but the threat level at home had not been raised. In Israel, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said the killing of the al-Qaeda leader was an "act of war," and vowed that the US would continue its mission, the AP reports.

– Vietnam has sent in troops to contain a rare protest by ethnic Hmong Christians, some of whom were calling for an independent kingdom. The demonstration by as many as 7,000 people in the far- flung mountains of Dien Bien Province began several days ago, but details were scant from the hard-to-access region. The government indicated the unrest was still going on. Elsewhere in Syria, protesters burned posters of President Bashar al-Assad outside the Syrian embassy in Athens today, in solidarity with anti-government protesters in Bahrain.

– Syria has agreed to let Kuwait replace it as a candidate for a seat on the UN's Human Rights Council, UN diplomats tell Reuters. Syria had been expected to run as a candidate for the Asian category, but it agreed to let Kuwait replace it after its Arab neighbors pressured it to do so. Syria had also been expected to run as a candidate for the entire 47-nation council.

– Syrian tanks rolled into the city of Latakia today, in what appears to be the biggest show of force yet in the seven-week-old uprising, reports al-Jazeera. Activists say more than 100 people have been killed in the crackdown, though it's not clear how many of those are civilians. The news comes as the UN's human rights chief warned today that the situation in Syria is getting worse, reports the Wall Street Journal.

– A 28-year-old Syrian man who broke through an Israeli fence to join Palestinian protesters in the Golan Heights has turned himself in to Israeli authorities. Hassan Hijazi says he hitch-hiked and rode a bus with Israeli soldiers to Tel Aviv after pushing through an Israeli frontier fence with Palestinian protesters. "It was my dream to reach Jaffa," he told an Israeli TV station, referring to the biblical city now a part of Israel's commercial hub. "I asked my friends if I could go to Tel Aviv and they said yes, because there are Israeli soldiers there." Hijazi, who says he works for the Syrian intelligence service, is being held on suspicion of entering Israel illegally.

– The Obama administration has ramped up pressure on Syria's Bashar al-Assad by slapping sanctions on the Syrian president and other top officials, reports the New York Times. “The actions the administration has taken today send an unequivocal message to President Assad, the Syrian leadership, and regime insiders that they will be held accountable for the ongoing violence and repression in Syria,” said the acting under secretary for terrorism. The US and the European Union had previously avoided sanctions against Assad personally, notes Reuters.

– Syria dropped its bid for a seat on the UN Human Rights Council today, in the face of mounting international pressure. Kuwait, under pressure from Western countries, stepped in to replace Syria as one of 15 nations elected today to the controversial council, the AP reports. The General Assembly elected Kuwait along with India, Indonesia, and the Philippines on a "clean slate" of Asian nations for three-year terms on the council, which has been roiled by the Syrian crisis.

– As NATO continues to pound Moammar Gadhafi's forces, the Libyan strongman's youngest son today made his first public appearance since the beginning of the conflict. Seif al-Islam Gadhafi told reporters in Tripoli that his father is still in charge and that he will rule until the end, reports the Telegraph. Seif al-Islam Gadhafi's appearance comes as NATO continues to pound his forces with air strikes, and as fighting rages in Yemen between pro- and anti-government forces, notes Reuters.

– Moammar Gadhafi's government says it is ready for a ceasefire with rebel forces, but only if NATO halts its air strikes against Libya, reports the BBC. The government is also demanding that rebels stop their attacks on Gadhafi's forces and negotiate a peaceful end to the conflict. The proposal comes on the heels of peace overtures to Spain and other foreign countries, notes Reuters.

– Bashar al-Assad has granted a general amnesty to all members of political movements, including the Muslim Brotherhood, following 10 weeks of protests against his 11-year rule. The amnesty covers “all members of political movements, including the Muslim Brotherhood,” state television said, after 10 weeks of protests against his 11-year rule and a military crackdown which has drawn international condemnation. The Brotherhood led an armed uprising against Assad's father in 1982. Membership of the Brotherhood, which led an armed uprising against Assad's father in 1982, is punishable by death in Syria.

– China's Li Na became the first Asian to win the French Open yesterday, defeating Italy's Francesca Schiavone in straight sets, and the head of the Asian Tennis Federation says Li's victory has "torn down a psychological barrier" for Asian players, Reuters reports. The sixth-seeded Li beat Schiavone to become the first Chinese player to win a Grand Slam tournament, and the first Asian to do so at Roland Garros. "It's a great day for Asian tennis," the head of the ATF says. "It's been a long time since we had an Asian player win a Grand Slam."

– The International Criminal Court has indicted Syrian President Bashar al-Assad on charges of crimes against humanity for his violent crackdown on protesters, Reuters reports. The ICC says Assad ordered the killing of scores of security men in the restive town of Jisr al-Shughour over the weekend, and ordered his forces to open fire on protesters today. The crackdown came a day after UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon warned that Syria was on the brink of civil war. More than 1,000 people have been killed in three months of unrest in Syria, according to Reuters.

– Syrian forces opened fire on protesters today, killing at least five, after Friday prayers, in the first reported use of air power to quell the three-month uprising, according to the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights. Helicopters also opened fire on the ground, in a northwestern town, after security forces on the ground killed five protesters, said the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights. Meanwhile, refugees fleeing the country tell Reuters troops have been battling each other in Jisr al-Shughour, a town near the Turkish border where the government said more than 120 soldiers were killed last weekend.

– Asian markets were mixed in early trading today, with Japan's Nikkei down 1.1% and Australia's S&P/ASX 200 down 0.8%, as investors digested a slew of downbeat economic reports from the US and Europe. China's markets were down for a third straight day, the AP reports, as the government announced that the country's money supply growth hit a 30-month low in May.

– The G20 has agreed to monitor world supplies of key grains to prevent speculation and drive up food prices, according to a draft statement seen by Reuters. Farm ministers from the group will meet in Paris next week, and will also call on their finance ministers to adopt stricter regulations for food derivatives markets. Meanwhile, Bashar al-Assad’s cousin, Rami Makhlouf, says he’s quitting the Syrian business scene, owes his fortune to his cousin and his role as a hate figure for protesters to his cousin. “I wish Syria had 10 Rami Makhloufs,” he told businessmen last year.

– If Bashar al-Assad doesn’t start talking to opposition leaders soon, Syria could slip into civil war—and the rest of the Middle East could be in real danger, a cousin of the Syrian president tells the Wall Street Journal. “If there is no rapprochement between President Assad and the Syrian people, the situation in Syria could turn into a civil war,” said the cousin, identified only as Ammar. “We are afraid of a civil war in the region,” he said. “The whole of the Middle East is on the brink of a civil war.” The Journal notes that Assad has made no secret of his support for terror groups.

– Jack in the Box has become the latest fast-food chain to ditch toys from kids' meals, a spokesman tells Reuters. The chain, under pressure from health groups and regulators to ditch marketing of unhealthy food to kids, has made the change at stores in Los Angeles, a spokesman said. The toys will still be sold at stores in Chicago, New York, and Las Vegas, the spokesman said. Click here for more.

– Syrian troops moved up to seal off the border with Turkey today, as thousands of refugees—many of them women and children—continued to pour in from across the border. Turkey has been increasing its rhetoric against Syria, calling Bashar al-Assad’s crackdown “savagery,” but analysts say Turkey is still holding out hope for a change of heart in Assad, according to Reuters. “I think the main thing on the agenda this time may be the situation on the border,” said an Afghan analyst in Kabul. Meanwhile, exiled Syrian opposition figures urged Russia today to persuade Assad to resign, warning that Moscow risked being left behind by history unless it withdrew its support for the leader, reports Reuters. Senior Russian officials, who have thwarted Western attempts to condemn Assad for crushing protests against his rule, held a meeting with some of Assad’s most vociferous critics in Moscow. The meeting was seen as a possible sign the Kremlin might be hedging its bets and trying to ensure its clout in the Middle Eastern country if Assad is toppled.

– Tens of thousands of protesters took to the streets across Syria today, defying a military crackdown, in the biggest demonstrations since the uprising began three months ago, according to a rights lawyer. Bashar al-Assad's forces killed at least 24 civilians, according to the lawyer, who told al-Jazeera that more than 200 people have been killed in the three months of protests. In one of the biggest demonstrations since the uprising began, Kurds marched in the northeastern city of Amouda, carrying signs that read, " Bashar get out of our lives." The protests were also held after Friday prayers across the country, from towns near the western Lebanese border to the desert regions near Iraq in the east. Syria's opposition, weakened by half a century of oppression under the Baath party, is united in demanding change but divided over how to achieve it, Reuters reports.

– Moammar Gadhafi's forces have taken control of the oil port of Ras Lanuf, opening the way for the first oil exports from Libya since the dictator's ouster and death, the Wall Street Journal reports. Gadhafi's forces also took control of the Bin Jawad oil field, which sits on the other side of the Ras Lanuf River from the city of Ras Lanuf, according to al-Jazeera. Gadhafi's forces have also taken control of the Bin Jawad town of Ras Lanuf, which is on the other side of the river from the city of Zawiyah. The Journal notes that Gadhafi's forces have also taken control of the Bin Jawad town of Kikla, which is on the other side of the river from the city of Zawiyah.

– New York City will open its clerk's offices Sunday, July 24, to allow same-sex couples to wed on the first day the state's gay marriage bill goes into effect, officials said on Wednesday. City clerk's offices in the five boroughs normally are closed on weekends, but Mayor Michael Bloomberg said that for this special occasion they will be open. "This is a historic moment for New York, a moment many couples have waited years and even decades to see—and we are not going to make them wait one day longer than they have to," Bloomberg said in a statement. City Clerk Michael McSweeney added that his office expected "large numbers of people" on the first day.

– Divers searching a Russian river boat which sank in the Volga over the weekend said they saw more than a hundred bodies trapped inside, reports Reuters. In 1986 Russia suffered one of its worst shipping disasters when passenger liner the Admiral Nakhimov hit the cargo ship Pyotr Vasev off the Black Sea port of Novorossiysk. At least 423 passengers and crew died. Divers searching the boat said they saw more than a hundred bodies trapped inside.

– Apple has paid its first victim over location data collected on its phones. South Korean lawyer Kim Hyung-suk, who used the iPhone 4S, received about $600,000 after a court ordered Apple to pay him in compensation following a court order in May, officials at the Changwon District Court tell Reuters. It's the first such payout by the US company, and the lawyer's law firm says the payment was made last month. Apple collected the data without the user's consent after the phone was launched in South Korea in 2009. The company has also collected data on users of other phones, but this is the first time it has been found to have done so on an iPhone.

– At least 30 people were killed over the weekend in factional fighting between pro- and anti-Assad residents of the Syrian city of Homs, the head of the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights tells Reuters. Residents of the city, which has been a hotbed of protests against President Bashar al-Assad, started fighting on Saturday after the bodies of kidnapped Assad supporters were returned to their relatives. Ten mourners were killed at a funeral for another 10 people killed by security forces on Monday. Syrian troops and militiamen killed 16 people in attacks in the city of Homs on Tuesday, residents said, an escalation of a crackdown against a focal point for pro-democracy protests. Among those killed were 10 mourners at a funeral for another 10 people who were killed by security forces on Monday, the Local Coordinations Committee, an activists group, said. Syrian authorities have expelled most foreign journalists, making it hard to verify activist accounts or official statements.

– Usain Bolt needed a late surge to narrowly beat fellow Jamaican Nesta Carter in the 100 meters at the Monaco Diamond League meeting on Friday. Bolt overhauled his compatriot, who also ran his season's best of 9.90, in the last 15 meters while American Michael Rodgers finished third with 9.96. It was not the best start, but I executed well overall," Bolt told reporters after finding his form in his last scheduled meeting ahead of next month's world championships. Michael Phelps has won 14 Olympic gold medals, 22 world championship titles, and set numerous world records, yet the American still regards himself as just a regular guy. "In my eyes, I consider myself a normal person," he told reporters at a media conference stuffed full of reporters, television cameras, and photographers. "Yeah, there are a lot more cameras pointing at me right now than most other people, but this is my life. This is what I consider normal."

– Hosni Mubarak's trial has been postponed until next week at the earliest, a court announced today, following clashes between protesters and the army over the weekend. The court also ordered the retrial of Mubarak's former interior minister, Rafaat Shehata, who is accused of ordering the killing of protesters. Mubarak and his sons Gamal and Alaa will also be retried, Reuters reports. The developments come as the US and other Western powers step up their criticism of Bashar al-Assad's regime. The White House said it was "concerned" by reports of human rights abuses, while the European Union said it was looking into reports of torture and other violations of human rights.

– If you're looking for a safe place to park your money in the midst of the European debt crisis, look no further than Britain, according to a Reuters poll of 14 investment managers. The average allocation to UK stocks rose 3 percentage points to 15.5% in July, while allocations to US stocks fell 2 percentage points and those to euro zone stocks dropped 3 percentage points. "The market is starting to get a little bit nervous about sovereign debt problems in the euro zone and the US, so it's a good time to invest in Britain as a safe haven," one investment manager tells the Telegraph.

– If you're looking for a safe place to park your money, Barron's thinks you should head to Ford. The auto company's shares could rise 25% as it cuts debt, rolls out new models, and tries to expand in China and India, where it has been a laggard, Barron's said in its August 1 edition. Unlike rivals General Motors and Chrysler, Ford was able to avoid bankruptcy and government bailouts by taking on billions of dollars of debt in 2006, when capital markets were still open. The US dollar also surged against the Swiss franc and the euro today, Reuters reports.

– Libyan rebels say they are in control of a strategic town south of Tripoli that has been held by Moammar Gadhafi's forces for weeks. The rebel flag flies over Bir al-Ghanam, which is the closest point the rebels have come to Gadhafi's stronghold of Tripoli, Reuters reports. The town lies on a highway leading north to the Mediterranean coast and on to Tripoli. Rebel commanders in the region said on Saturday they had seized control of Bir al-Ghanam in an offensive in which four anti-Gadhafi fighters had died. Taking the town—which lies on a highway leading north to the Mediterranean coast and on to Tripoli—would break weeks of stalemate during which rebels have been unable to make big advances despite NATO air strikes on government forces.

– Protests broke out across the Middle East and North Africa today, as demonstrators took to the streets in Bahrain, Libya, Yemen, and Syria, al-Jazeera reports. In Libya, protesters took to the streets for a second day, defying a state of emergency that has been in place since last week. In Yemen, protesters took to the streets for a second day as President Ali Abdullah Saleh continues to refuse to step down, Reuters reports. In Syria, government forces killed at least 15 people today as they continued their assault on the city of Homs. Click for more.

– Qantas isn’t the first airline to offer in-flight entertainment, but it’s probably the first to offer a 50-minute French film that purports to explain the female orgasm. “The Female Orgasm Explained” is included in the airline’s “The Edge” video on demand channel, complete with a warning that it’s for mature audiences only, Reuters reports. Qantas says it screened the film before licensing it, adding that it’s only available on long-haul flights.

– The UN Security Council will hold an emergency meeting today to discuss the situation in Syria, according to a Western diplomat. The meeting comes as the death toll in the five-month uprising rose to more than 3,500, according to the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights, which estimates that more than 200 civilians were killed yesterday. – A member of the Royal Air Force's Red Arrows aerobatic team was killed today when his plane crashed at an air festival on the coast of England, reports Reuters. The 33-year-old pilot was killed when his plane crashed near an airport some 100 miles from London.

– With the fall of Moammar Gadhafi, the world is turning its attention to Syria. The US, Britain, France, Germany, and Portugal are drafting a UN Security Council resolution that would blacklist Syrian firms and call for sanctions against President Bashar al-Assad and other top officials, according to Reuters. The resolution would also refer Syria to the permanent war crimes tribunal at the Hague. “The international community will now think that its strong intervention in the struggle... will resolve the situation,” said opposition figure Louay Hussein. “Libya has raised the morale of the West and it will have a bigger excuse to intervene.” Meanwhile, in Syria, security forces opened fire on protesters in the town of Rankus, killing at least six, according to the New York Times.

– Bashar al-Assad held an iftar meal for Islamic leaders in Damascus last night, blaming the unrest in Syria on “morality and ethics” in the country, but his security forces continued their brutal crackdown on protesters. Activists say security forces raided an eastern tribal region for a second day today, extending the crack—down on pro-democracy protests. The US, Britain, France, Germany, and Portugal have circulated a draft resolution that calls for sanctions against Syrian President Bashar al-Assad, influential members of his family and close associates, and they say they want to put it to a vote as soon as possible. They say they want to put it to a vote as soon as possible. Syrian TV shows footage of an iftar meal in Damascus hosted by beleaguered president Bashar al-Assad for Islamic leaders. Iftar marks the fasting day during the holy month of Ramadan. Assad said Ramadan was a time for doing good deeds, adding that the army was protecting the nation. But activists say that Syrian forces raided an eastern tribal region for a second day today, extending the crack—down on pro-democracy protests.

– New Japanese Prime Minister Yoshihiko Noda picked a relatively lightweight lawmaker as finance minister on Friday, signaling the fiscally conservative leader intends to call the shots on key economic policies himself. Noda, a former finance minister elected this week as Japan's sixth prime minister in five years, tapped the 49-year-old Jun Azumi, a former parliamentary affairs chief, for the finance portfolio after his first choice turned it down, reports Reuters. If he were a veteran lawmaker, the new finance minister might have clashed with Noda on some issues. – Israel evacuated its ambassador to Egypt today after protesters smashed the windows of the embassy and burned the Israeli flag, reports Reuters. The move came a day after protesters burned the Israeli flag and threw documents through the windows of the embassy in Cairo. Egypt's army rulers vowed to try those behind the violence, as they struggled to contain public fury against the Jewish state whilefending off US criticism. Washington has poured billions of dollars in military aid into Egypt since it made peace with Israel in 1979 and urged Cairo to protect the mission after protesters hurled embassy documents from the windows of the building and removed and burnt the Israeli flag.

– Turkey's prime minister is on a visit to Egypt, and in an interview published in an Egyptian newspaper yesterday, Recep Tayyip Erdogan said he feared Syria would end up in civil war. “I fear that matters will end in civil war between the Alawites and the Sunnis,” he said, referring to Bashar al-Assad's sect. Erdogan is on a visit to deepen Turkey's ties with Egypt, and is calling for the Palestinian flag to be raised over the United Nations, Reuters reports. Meanwhile, in Libya, loyalists of Moammar Gadhafi killed 15 guards in an attack on an oil refinery, in an apparent attempt to disrupt a drive by Libya's new rulers to seize the ousted leader's last bastions and revive the oil-based economy. The National Transitional Council says that as long as Gadhafi remains on the run, he is capable of attracting followers to a dangerous insurgency.

– Ireland pulled off the biggest upset in international rugby history today, beating Australia 15-6 in Auckland. "It's the proudest moment of my career," said Ireland captain Brian O'Driscoll, who scored a try. "To beat Australia in New Zealand is a massive feather in our cap." The Wallabies, who had won their last 16 Tests, scored a try through James O'Connor but were unable to find the try line. "I thought we were second-best for most of the game," said Australian coach Robbie Deans. "We were second-best at the scrum and they were second-best at the breakdown."

– Turkey has suspended talks with Syria and may impose sanctions, Prime Minister Tayyip Erdogan said today, the clearest sign yet that Ankara has parted ways with President Bashar al-Assad over his bloody crackdown on anti-government protesters. Turkey has long maintained close relations with Syria, urging him to end a military crackdown on a popular uprising and to launch democratic reforms, Reuters reports. In other Syria news: Syrian tanks rolled into the city of Latakia today, in response to the Turkish move, the AP reports. Activists say more than 100 people have been killed in the city, which has long been a bastion of support for the regime. Tanks and armored vehicles rolled into the town of Ras al-Ain today, in response to the Turkish move, according to a report in the state-run news agency. Activists say security forces opened fire on protesters as they tried to march on the presidential palace. In other Syria news: Syria's state-run news agency today reported that the army has killed more than 100 "peaceful protesters" in the town of Rankus, according to a report in the state-run al-Jazeera. – Pope Benedict met with victims of clerical sex abuse in Germany today and expressed his "deep regret" for their suffering, the Vatican said in a statement. The meeting took place in a seminary in Erfurt, in eastern Germany, and was similar to those held by Benedict on other recent trips, the Vatican said. The meeting came on the second day of Benedict's four-day trip to Germany, where record numbers of Catholics have officially left the faith in protest at clerical abuse, and where the church faces some 600 requests for compensation. The pope was "moved and deeply shaken," and assured victims the church was "committed to the promotion of effective measures to protect children," the Vatican said. Click for more.

– New moms are still getting free infant formula samples at many hospitals, according to a new report—and experts worry that the trend could undermine official recommendations that they stick to breastfeeding until their baby is at least six months old. The number of hospitals handing out the samples has dropped dramatically over the last few years, but they're still the norm at many facilities, according to the report by Reuters Health and the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists. "If a hospital gives it out... the patient thinks it's the best thing for the baby," one expert tells the New York Daily News. – tanks rolled into a Syrian town yesterday, in the first major fighting since the uprising against President Bashar al-Assad's regime began six weeks ago. The army defectors, who have taken over the town of Rankus and are holed up in a mosque, have attacked government forces in other towns, but it's not clear how serious the defectors are, the New York Times reports. Syria's civil war "appears to be in danger of descending into a sectarian civil war with wider regional consequences," says the Times, which notes that sectarian tensions could spill over into Iraq, where Sunnis are worried about losing their influence.

– The newly formed Syrian opposition coalition is calling on the international community to protect the Syrian people from the "illegitimate" regime of Bashar al-Assad. The Syrian National Council rejected foreign intervention in the country, but said the outside world had a "humanitarian obligation" to protect the people, reports Reuters. The declaration and support for the National Council was a significant show of unity from the Syrian opposition after six months of mostly non-violent protests against Assad, who has begun to be overtaken by more violent resistance. Armed insurgents, mostly in the central Homs region and in the northwestern province of Idlib near Turkey, have been so far outgunned.

– Turkey says it will impose sanctions on Syria despite the UN’s blocking of any sanctions against President Bashar al-Assad for his crackdown on dissent. Turkey’s prime minister is expected to visit refugee camps in Hatay, where more than 7,000 Syrians have taken refuge, after he returns from South Africa this week, Reuters reports. Meanwhile, Turkey’s military will conduct an exercise in the southern province of Hatay, where more than 7,000 Syrians have taken refuge from Syrian President Bashar al-Assad’s security forces. The October 5-13 mobilization exercise, announced on the military’s website on Tuesday, may coincide with a visit that Prime Minister Tayyip Erdogan is expected to make to refugee camps in Hatay after he returns from South Africa this week. The army said the exercise would involve the 39th mechanized infantry brigade and 730 reserve soldiers.
