– A Syrian military officer has defected and declared that "all options are on the table" when it comes to President Bashar al-Assad. "There is no option left but to use force to topple the regime," the colonel tells Reuters. "We are talking about a military coup, not a political one." Turkey has been increasing its pressure on Syria with border military exercises, economic sanctions, and the harboring of Syrian opposition groups and army defectors, but it must tread carefully to avoid spurring Syrian counter- measures. Meanwhile, Syrian security forces killed at least two people when they opened fire on tens of thousands of mourners at the funeral of a Kurdish opposition figure, activists say. The funeral of Meshaal al-Tammo in the eastern Syrian city of Qamishli turned into a protest against Assad, with mourners chanting anti-Assad slogans and calling on him to step down.

– Syria's newly formed opposition coalition wants Western countries to do more to support it and get recognition once it has a legitimate government in place, the group's de facto leader told a French TV station today. The Syrian National Council is "the only legitimate representative of the Syrian people," Burhan Ghalioun said, but Western nations "are not doing enough to pressure Russia into changing its stance on Syria and must do more to support the burgeoning opposition," according to Reuters.

– Bashar al-Assad lifted a 41-year state of emergency in Syria today, but his security forces fired on a funeral procession in central Damascus, killing three and injuring 20. The violence came a day after the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights warned of a possible civil war in the country, which has seen some of the worst violence of the uprising. In other Syria news: Assad formed a committee today to draft a new constitution in four months, the official news agency said, following a series of new laws that gave Syrians more freedom on paper after months of popular unrest. Under pressure from street protests demanding the end to 41 years of Assad family rule, the president has lifted a state of emergency and promised parliamentary elections by February. The move raised the possibility that a clause designating his Baath Party, which seized power in a 1963 coup, could be scrapped, Reuters reports.

– Syrian tanks rolled into the flashpoint city of Homs today, in what activists say is the biggest offensive yet in the area, and one of the deadliest days in the seven-month uprising. At least 25 people were killed, one of the highest daily death tolls in the city, which has seen growing armed resistance to President Bashar al-Assad's crackdown, residents tell Reuters. The Arab League, meanwhile, stopped short of suspending Syria, but called on the government and opposition to negotiate an end to the violence. “We will call all of the parties of the opposition and government to hold a dialogue within 15 days,” the League's secretary general said after the meeting, according to al-Jazeera.

– The death of Moammar Gadhafi has been followed by a wave of anti-government protests across the Arab world, with at least 13 people killed by security forces in the Syrian cities of Homs and Hama, Reuters reports. Anti-government protesters spread across Syria—fueled even more by the death of the longest-serving leader in the Arab world. Amateur video that could not be independently verified by Reuters showed demonstrators celebrating Gadhafi's death and calling for Syrian President Bashar al-Assad to go. Taking to the streets Thursday night—and after Friday prayers—protests said security was increased. Most of the protesters were killed in the central city of Homs and in Hama in the north—both hotbeds for anti- Bashar activism.

– The European Union is readying new sanctions against Iran if it doesn't do more to curb its nuclear program, and is also readying new sanctions against Syria if Bashar al-Assad's regime continues its bloody crackdown on civilians, reports the Wall Street Journal. EU leaders called on Iran to engage in "constructive and substantial talks" with Western powers to solve the nuclear question, notes Reuters. They also warned Syria that the EU will impose further and more comprehensive measures as long as the repression of the civilian population continues.

– Bashar al-Assad met with Arab League officials in Damascus today, and emerged with little to show for it, according to Syrian activists. At least 20 people were killed, including nine soldiers and 11 civilians, according to the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights. The Arab League said the talks were "cordial and frank," but that they would meet again on Oct. 30 in Doha, Qatar, or Damascus. France's foreign minister, meanwhile, said Assad's government will "almost certainly fall under the pressure of protests and sanctions," but it will take time because of the "complexity of internal and regional politics," reports Reuters.

– The International Criminal Court has issued an arrest warrant for Moammar Gadhafi, accusing the Libyan leader of crimes against humanity during the conflict in his country, the BBC reports. The warrant was issued after Libyan authorities failed to arrest Gadhafi or hand him over to the ICC. Gadhafi "is accused of crimes against humanity, including murder, rape, torture, persecution, and extermination," said ICC chief prosecutor Luis Moreno-Ocampo in a statement. "He is also accused of crimes against humanity by terrorizing his own people." Gadhafi's whereabouts are unknown.

– A prominent Israeli non-governmental organization says Israel is forcing Palestinians out of East Jerusalem as part of a deliberate policy that might constitute a war crime. The Israeli Committee Against House Demolitions has presented the UN with its findings and demanded an inquiry, saying Israel targeted Palestinians by demolishing homes, revoking residency, and eroding quality of life. “We are witnessing a process of ethnic displacement,” said Michael Sfard, a lawyer who helped draw up a 73-page report into the issue. Jerusalem’s mayor, however, rejected the allegations, saying that Israel has only destroyed Palestinian homes in the West Bank, not East Jerusalem. The Israeli Committee Against House Demolitions has presented the UN with its findings and demanded an inquiry, saying Israel targeted Palestinians by demolishing homes, revoking residency, and eroding quality of life. In other Syria news: NATO ruled out the possibility of military intervention in Syria today, but said Damascus should draw lessons from Libya, where NATO backed rebels won a civil war that resulted in the killing of long-serving leader Muammar Gaddafi. Western powers have been tightening sanctions on Syria but have shown no appetite to repeat their Libyan operation in the Middle Eastern nation where protesters have demanded outside protection from a crackdown that has killed 3,000 people.

– The Red Cross is pressing Syrian authorities for wider access to thousands of detainees arrested in pro-democracy protests, while insisting that its own strict terms be met. In an interview with Reuters, Jakob Kellenberger, president of the International Committee of the Red Cross, said that the independent humanitarian agency would assess its role after an upcoming visit to a detention center in Aleppo. Syria opened its prisons for the first time in September, allowing ICRC officials to visit Damascus central prison, which has 6,000 inmates, but that is the only facility the Red Cross has seen. Kellenberger said the Red Cross is also pressing for the release of all political prisoners.

– The UN's human rights chief warned today that Syria is on the brink of civil war, as government forces continued their assault on Homs. The violence has killed more than 200 people in the past 24 hours, according to the New York Times, which notes that the death toll in Homs is more than double the number of people killed in other parts of Syria over the same period. The UN High Commissioner for Human Rights, Navi Pillay, told the UN Security Council that defectors are increasing the risk of a Libyan-style civil war, Reuters reports. "Where basic human rights are trampled and peaceful demands for change met by brutal violence, people are eventually compelled to have recourse to rebellion against tyranny and oppression," Pillay said. In other Syria news: Syrian tanks rolled into the Baba Amr district of Homs today, in what appears to be an attempt to crush resistance, the BBC reports. Government forces have also been reported to be shelling the Baba Amr neighborhood, which is home to a number of elite Republican Guards members who have defected.

– The Arab League suspended Syria today, calling on President Bashar al-Assad's regime to end its violent crackdown on protesters, reports Reuters. Syria's representative to the Arab League said the move violated the organization's charter and showed that it was "serving a Western and American agenda." Hours after the League's decision, hundreds of Assad supporters attacked the Saudi Arabian embassy in Damascus and Turkish and French consulates in the city of Latakia, residents said. The Arab League will impose economic and political sanctions on Damascus and has appealed to member states to withdraw their ambassadors, said Qatar's Prime Minister Sheikh Hamad bin Jassim al-Thani.

– Hours after the Arab League suspended Syria for failing to end its bloody crackdown on protesters, supporters of President Bashar al-Assad attacked the United Arab Emirates' embassy in Damascus, hurling stones and debris at the building and smearing its walls with graffiti, witnesses tell Reuters. France recalled its ambassador to Damascus and the Arab League said it would suspend Syria's membership if it didn't end its crackdown, which has killed more than 5,000 people over the last eight months. In other Syria developments: The Syrian National Council, an opposition group, called for a general strike tomorrow to protest the Arab League's decision, al-Jazeera reports. "We call on the Syrian people to hold a general strike tomorrow to protest the Arab League's decision to suspend Syria's membership in the Arab League," said a statement from the group. The Syrian army, meanwhile, continued its assault on Homs, opening fire on hundreds of protesters in the Baba Amr district, the New York Times reports. The violence comes a day after the UN's High Commissioner for Human Rights warned that the situation in Syria was "on the brink of civil war."

– With the Arab League deadline for Syria to comply with its peace plan looming, President Bashar al-Assad told Britain's Sunday Times that "the conflict will continue and the pressure to subjugate Syria will continue." Assad blamed militants for the unrest, and said the government's role is to fight these militants, protect civilians, and restore stability. "However, I assure you that Syria will not bow down and that it will continue to resist the pressure being imposed on it," he said. Hillary Clinton, meanwhile, warned that Syria could slide into civil war, Reuters reports. "I think there could be a civil war with a very determined and well—armed and eventually well—financed opposition that is, if not directed by defectors from the army, certainly influenced by defectors from the army," she said. "We're already seeing that, something that we hate to see because we are in favor of a peaceful protest and a nonviolent opposition."

– BP has set up a fund to compensate victims of the Gulf oil spill, but those who want to sue the company will have to give up that right, says Kenneth Feinberg, the administrator of the 9/11 compensation fund. The $20 billion fund will be "substantially larger" than the one set up by BP, Feinberg tells the New York Times. "There will be more money in this fund than there was in the 9/11 fund," he says. "But it will be more generous than the amount of money that BP has already paid out."

– BP CEO Tony Hayward is taking flak for taking a day off to go sailing on the Isle of Wight. Environmental groups say it's an insult to those affected by the Gulf oil spill, and the White House says it's one of a "long line of PR gaffes and mistakes" by Hayward. BP defended Hayward, saying it was his first day off since the spill began, the BBC reports.

– The US Coast Guard has declared a "very serious spill" in the Gulf of Mexico after oil started leaking from a damaged well almost a mile below the surface. Robotic submersibles are being used to try to stop oil leaking from a damaged well almost a mile below the surface, reports the BBC. Some 1,000 barrels of oil a day are leaking into the sea from the damaged well, officials say. They say the oil leak has the potential to damage beaches, barrier islands, and wetlands across the coastline. A nearby oil platform has been evacuated as a precaution.

– BP says it has managed to seal the smallest of the three leaks leaking oil into the Gulf of Mexico. Oil is still gushing into the sea at a rate of about 800,000 liters a day, but officials say working with only two leaks makes tackling the spill easier. A controlled burn of the slick to remove oil from open water has also begun, the AP reports. And a special containment box to funnel oil to the surface is being sent to the site. Engineers plan to lower the 100-ton concrete and steel box over the site on Thursday, using remote-controlled submarines, officials say. The US is to carry out a controlled burn of some of the leaked oil. But the oil reached a beach for the first time yesterday, officials confirmed. The spill was set off by an explosion that destroyed the Deepwater Horizon rig off Louisiana last month.

– The feds are ramping up efforts to contain the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, with the US Coast Guard sending ships to the scene and Florida declaring a state of emergency. Up to 5,000 barrels of oil a day are leaking, five times the amount previously thought to be leaking from the Deepwater Horizon rig when it exploded last week, the BBC reports. Florida Gov. Charlie Crist, who has declared a state of emergency in four counties along the coast, says the oil slick is "generally moving in a northerly direction and threatens Florida's coast." The spill is already threatening three other states.

– President Obama flew to Louisiana today to see the damage being done to the coast by a massive oil spill and promised that his administration would " spare no effort" to contain it. "This is an unprecedented environmental disaster," he said. "The federal government will do whatever is necessary to support the states of Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama, and Florida in their efforts to contain this oil spill." Louisiana Gov. Bobby Jindal warned that the spill was threatening the state's way of life, the BBC reports. "This is not just an oil spill, this is an environmental disaster," he said. "It's going to do a lot of damage."

– The explosion that killed 11 workers on an oil rig in the Gulf of Mexico was caused by an exploding bubble of methane gas, according to a BP report into the incident. Workers on the rig described hearing screaming and hollering and said people leapt into the sea to escape, the Telegraph reports. Eye witnesses also said safety mechanisms did not function and that workers were taken by surprise. More than 160 miles of protective booms had been deployed. BP is trying to funnel the leaking oil to the surface. A containment device lowered over the well to funnel oil to the surface had to be moved on Saturday after ice—like crystals began accumulating inside it. BP chief operating officer Doug Suttles said the 98-ton concrete—and—steel box had to be moved, after ice—like crystals began accumulating inside it. He said BP's engineers hoped they could find a solution to the problem. The aim is to contain as much as 85% of the escaping oil and then funnel it into a waiting tanker on the surface. The latest bid to plug the gushing well comes after previous attempts to stem the flow failed. A growing slick from the BP-leased rig is threatening an environmental disaster along US coasts.

– The White House is demanding that BP clarify whether it will pay the full clean-up costs of the Gulf oil spill. The administration wants to make sure that BP will honor its commitment not to limit payments for damages to a US statutory cap of $75 million, the New York Times reports. Meanwhile, BP's latest attempt to contain the oil—a so-called "top hat" containment dome—has been delayed by a few days, the BBC reports.

– The first oil from the Gulf spill has entered an ocean current that could carry it to Florida and up the east coast of the US. A small portion of oil sheen is in the Loop Current, which circulates in the Gulf, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration says. Federal officials including Interior Secretary Ken Salazar are to face questioning by senators today. Meanwhile, a top coast guard official told the US Senate that oil from the spill may reach the southern Florida coastline, the BBC reports. Any oil that does wash up is likely to be in the form of tarballs, which are a little easier to manage.

– The US government has told BP it has "fallen short" in its ability to provide accurate information about the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, the BBC reports. In a letter to the company, the Obama administration demanded that BP "act in a transparent manner and promptly make all information public." The US has ordered BP to use a less toxic chemical to contain the oil, which has now reached Louisiana and is threatening Florida and Cuba. BP says it has siphoned 2,200 barrels of oil over the last 24 hours, down from an earlier estimate of 5,000 barrels. Two Greenpeace protesters unfurled a banner at BP's London headquarters yesterday, but there were no arrests.

– Interior Secretary Ken Salazar has promised to "keep our boot on BP's neck" until the oil spill is cleaned up. Salazar, who is on a tour of the Gulf, said the British company had missed its deadline to plug the well, but had agreed to pay clean-up costs beyond the current $75 million liability limit, the BBC reports. He also promised that BP would be "accountable, civilly, and in whatever way is necessary." Salazar's comments come as BP began sharing details of its internal investigation into the cause of the spill.

– BP says its latest plan to plug the gushing oil well in the Gulf of Mexico is going according to plan. The company is planning to pump mud into the well as early as Wednesday in its first attempt to plug the well using the so-called "top kill" method, reports the BBC. The procedure has a 60% to 70% chance of success, says BP COO Doug Suttles. "We have the best people working on this," he said. President Obama today extended a ban on deep-water drilling for six months.

– BP's latest attempt to plug its gushing oil well in the Gulf of Mexico has failed, the company announced today. The company will now shift to a new strategy, one that involves shooting mud into the gushing well in a bid to plug it. "We have been unable to overcome the flow," BP's chief operating officer told reporters, according to the BBC. The "top kill" operation is the first time BP has tried such a procedure.

– The Justice Department has launched a criminal and civil investigation into the Gulf oil spill after BP's latest attempt to plug the well failed. Attorney General Eric Holder did not say which companies or individuals were being targeted, the BBC reports. Earlier, BP launched a new attempt to try to contain the spill using undersea robots to cut off the fractured pipe and seal it with a cap. BP said the spill—the largest in US history—might be capped within 24 hours. Meanwhile, the US government said it would launch criminal and civil proceedings against BP. BP's shares fell sharply on Tuesday following the failure of its previous efforts to "top kill" the leak by pumping mud into the well.

– Oil giant BP says a containment cap placed on its gushing well in the Gulf of Mexico is now capturing around 10,000 barrels a day. That's about half the estimated 12,000 to 19,000 barrels leaking daily, and it could take 48 hours to know if the cap is working, the BBC reports. BP chief Tony Hayward told the BBC that the amount of oil being captured is lower than the amount that had been flowing. "As we speak, the containment cap is producing around 10,000 barrels of oil a day to the surface," he said.

– President Obama took his criticism of BP CEO Tony Hayward to a new level today, telling Today that Hayward "wouldn't be working for me after any of those statements." "I know whose ass to kick," he said. "I've visited Louisiana, and I've seen the damage that's been done to the coast. I want my life back, and the Gulf is—it's a big ocean, and it's going to take years to clean up. And I want BP to do better at getting money to people who are affected." The president's comments came as Nordea, a Nordic bank, announced that it had sold all its shares in BP, accusing the company of a lack of transparency over the oil spill, the BBC reports.

– British PM David Cameron will meet with President Obama at the White House this weekend to try to ease tensions over the Gulf oil spill, the BBC reports. London Mayor Boris Johnson says he'd like to see "a bit of cool heads rather than endlessly buck—passing and name—calling." Meanwhile, BP shares have dropped to their lowest level since 1997 amid investor fears that the company won't have the funds to clean up the spill and pay dividends.

– President Obama arrived in Mississippi today for his fourth visit to the Gulf of Mexico since the oil spill began, where he'll meet with residents and try to convince them that the federal government will take care of the spill's aftermath, the AP reports. He'll also visit Alabama and Florida. "The spill will have the same impact on the US psyche as 9/11," Obama told Politico. "It's going to shape how we think about the environment for years to come." BP shares fell 9% today.

– Shares in BP closed up almost 7% after the company agreed to set up a $20 billion compensation fund for victims of the Gulf oil spill. The move came after talks at the White House between President Obama and BP CEO Tony Hayward, the BBC reports. BP also announced that it would not be paying any dividends for the rest of the year.

– BP's share price took a nosedive today as the company announced that the cost of the Gulf of Mexico oil spill has now hit $2.7 billion. The figure includes cleanup costs, relief well drilling, grants to Gulf states, and claims paid, the BBC reports. The company's share price dived 11% in early trading. BP's share price has plunged since the oil disaster began. One of BP's top bosses is due in Aberdeen to reassure staff the company has no plans to leave the North Sea. The firm faces enormous costs for the Gulf of Mexico explosion, which left 11 people dead and caused a major leak. Bernard Looney, managing director of BP North Sea, has dismissed speculation the company was planning to sell North Sea assets to help fund the costs. He is expected to address staff in Aberdeen on Monday before flying offshore on Tuesday.

– Looks like Tony Hayward's days at the helm of BP are numbered. The oil giant has named Robert Dudley as its new chief of oil response, effective immediately, the BBC reports. Dudley, who joined BP 18 months ago and has 30 years' experience in the oil industry, will be responsible for cleanup efforts in the Gulf and for the company's recovery from the Deepwater Horizon oil spill. The 55-year-old, who grew up in Mississippi, has a "deep appreciation and affinity for the Gulf Coast," BP said in a statement. He will report to Hayward.

– The town of Jean Lafitte, La., may look like a ghost town in the wake of the BP oil spill, but it's far from it, the BBC reports. "It looks like a ghost town around here," says the town's mayor. "But there are those who are offering it qualified praise for the work it is doing." In fact, the town is now home to BP's workers, and local officials are meeting in the mayor's office to praise the company's efforts.

– BP's share price climbed more than 2% today on reports that the company is seeking investment from Middle Eastern sovereign wealth funds. BP refused to comment directly on the speculation, but said it welcomed new investors, the BBC reports. The company has been seen as a possible takeover target following the recent collapse in its share price. But BP again warned that the total cost is likely to be much higher.

The information is needed before BP is allowed to change caps on the oil well. Meanwhile, one of BP's partners in the deepwater well that exploded in April has refused to pay its share of the costs so far. One of BP's partners in the deepwater well, Anadarko, which owns 25% of the Macondo well, was asked to pay $ 272 million. Anadarko spokesman said it was going to withhold payment. BP said it was disappointed that the firm had “failed to live up to their obligations.” Meanwhile, BP says its operation to drill a relief well to stop the Gulf oil leak is slightly ahead of schedule. A spokeswoman for the company told the BBC it was “slightly ahead” of the original schedule of completion in August. Asked about comments made by Bob Dudley, the man in charge, that finishing by 27 July was possible but only—in a perfect world with no interruptions “in a perfect world with no interruptions.”

– BP successfully installed a new containment cap on its gushing oil well in the Gulf of Mexico today, reports the BBC. But it could be a while before engineers know for sure whether it will work, because thousands of barrels of oil are being allowed to spill freely until the cap is fitted. BP warned that the cap system has never been deployed at such depths, and that its efficiency and ability to contain the oil and gas can not be assured. It also said that the two relief wells being drilled remain the only way permanently to seal the leak. Click here for more.

– BP says it has stopped oil flowing into the Gulf of Mexico for the first time since the Deepwater Horizon rig exploded more than a month ago. President Obama welcomed the news as a "positive sign," but said it was still in the testing phase and that it was important to "get ahead of ourselves" before jumping to any conclusions, the BBC reports. The company began shutting the valves on a new cap yesterday, but a minor leak delayed the start of a key test to see if the well can handle the pressure of the flow.

– The US Coast Guard has told BP that it may have to remove the cap on its damaged oil well in the Gulf of Mexico. Thad Allen, the government’s official in charge of the clean-up, expressed concern that the cap was failing to prevent oil from leaking from the ocean floor, and ordered the company to submit a plan to reopen the well if the seepage is confirmed. BP has agreed to monitor the sea floor for signs of a new leak, the BBC reports. The company’s shares fell nearly 5% in London after the Coast Guard’s announcement.

– BP's plan to suck up the oil fouling the Gulf of Mexico may have to be put on hold as ships evacuate the area ahead of Tropical Storm Bonnie. Work on the relief wells that BP hopes to use to permanently stop the leak has been suspended, but the company says the well will remain capped while ships evacuate the area, the Guardian reports. Meanwhile, BP has confirmed it will begin deepwater drilling off Libya in the next few weeks.

– The amount of oil leaking into the Gulf of Mexico could be much less than previously thought, according to Kenneth Feinberg, the Obama administration's administrator of the BP oil spill compensation fund. Feinberg says he expects to pay out only 2.3 billion dollars in emergency claims from Gulf residents and businesses, the Guardian reports. He says half the claims received so far from victims have no supporting documents and are either "woefully inadequate" or have been rejected.

– The White House has released its long-awaited report on the causes of the Deepwater Horizon oil spill, and it finds that BP and its partners made a host of mistakes that led to the worst oil spill in US history. The report lays much of the blame on BP's lack of expertise in deep-sea drilling, the New York Times reports. The commission also faulted the US government for its slow response to the spill, which it said "could have been prevented or delayed." The full report is here.

– The US government's lawsuit against BP and other companies involved in the Gulf oil spill could cost the oil company billions in legal costs, the Guardian reports. The suit seeks unlimited damages to cover the costs of cleaning up the oil, the losses suffered by local businesses, and the damage done to the environment. "I've seen the devastation that this oil spill caused throughout the region, to individuals and to families, to communities and to businesses, to coastlines, to wetlands, as well as to wildlife," Attorney General Eric Holder told reporters. BP shares fell 3% in London trading in the wake of the lawsuit.

– The White House's long-awaited report on the Gulf oil spill is set to be released next week, and it's expected to blame BP, Transocean, and Halliburton for the disaster. The report is "utterly damning," according to the Guardian, and it predicts that similar disasters will happen because of industry complacency. "The safety failures of BP and its contractors and Transocean are systemic, due to a failure of management, and without reform without reform—and without reform, a repeat accident— may well occur," the report is expected to say. Meanwhile, a report out today from Britain's House of Commons warns that British taxpayers could end up footing the bill for any future oil spills, because current rules allow companies to avoid environmental responsibilities, reports the Telegraph.

– A huge oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico is already washing up on Louisiana's coast, and fishermen and shrimpers are filing lawsuits against the companies involved in the rig explosion. BP's insurance will cover the cost of the spill, but the company's shares have fallen 11% since the explosion, knocking about 20 billion off its market capitalization. The oil slick is already washing up on Louisiana's coast, and fishermen and shrimpers are worried about their livelihoods if it reaches shore. "It's time for the little shrimp to start coming out so we can catch those guys," the owner of an oyster and shrimp processing factory in Mississippi tells Reuters. "An oil spill will kill all of those guys."

– As the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico threatens to become one of the biggest in US history, Brazil is demanding answers. The country's energy regulator says it will ask oil companies operating offshore fields to provide information on their well control systems and to review emergency response protocols, Reuters reports. The vast majority of the 2 million barrels of oil Brazil produces daily come from offshore fields, and most of the country's future output is seen coming from ultra-deep water fields. "We will be judged by our response," BP CEO Tony Hayward says. "We will be judged by our reputation. Really, because the environment thinks differently. Just look at it."

– The cost of the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico has now passed $350 million, BP announced today, a figure that analysts tell Reuters suggests the final bill could be much higher. The company declined to give a further figure for the cost of containment, containment, relief well drilling, claims, and federal costs, but said the figure referred to the cost of spill response, containment, relief well drilling, payments to the Gulf Coast States to speed up their response plans, some compensation claims, and federal costs.

– The 5,000-barrels-a-day estimate of the amount of oil leaking from the Deepwater Horizon rig seems to be a massive underestimate, writes Justin Gillis at Reason. The government's "stated reason for not getting a better figure is weak indeed," and having greater precision "would not really help in any way."

– Two members of President Obama's Cabinet have demanded that BP CEO Tony Hayward explain the company's "true intentions" in the wake of the massive oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. In a letter to Hayward, Interior Secretary Ken Salazar and Homeland Security Secretary Janet Napolitano say the public has a right to know whether BP will "reimbursement all of the damage that has occurred or that will occur in the future as a result of the oil spill." They asked for an "immediate public clarification" of BP's "true intentions," Reuters reports. Meanwhile, BP said its latest attempt to contain the spill, a mile below the surface, was capturing about 20% of the oil leaking.

– The Coast Guard has deployed 1,105 ships to contain the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, the New Orleans Times-Picayune reports, and President Obama says he's ready to wrest control of the mess from BP. "I will be asking Congress to make BP pay for the cleanup operation," the president said in his weekly radio address today. "I will be asking Congress to make BP pay for the damage this spill is doing to the environment and to the economies of the region." Obama also promised to set up a presidential commission to investigate the cause of the spill and hold accountable those responsible, including Transocean and Halliburton, reports Reuters.

– The feds have told BP that if it doesn’t clean up the massive oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, it will be out of the cleanup business, the New York Times reports. The government has also threatened to fine the energy giant “absolutely,” a senior official tells Reuters. BP says it will make another attempt to plug the well tomorrow, but it has given the government only a 60% to 70% chance of success. Click here for more on the spill.

Obama, who has come under increased pressure to show leadership over the spill, suspended planned exploration off the coast of Alaska and canceled a pending lease sale in the Gulf of Mexico and a proposed lease sale off Virginia. He said even his daughter had asked him when the oil would stop leaking. "The president of the United States is responsible for this spill," he said. "My job is to make sure that the responsible party does everything in his power to contain it."

"If our laws were broken leading to this death and destruction, my solemn pledge is that we will bring those responsible to justice on behalf of the victims of this catastrophe and the people of the Gulf region," said President Obama, who met with the co-chairs of a commission that will investigate the accident. BP's familiar yellow and green logo is in need of an update, says Joe Daley, the founder of a website that connects logo designers with businesses. Daley is holding an online contest to find an appropriate replacement logo, with the winner getting the prize.

– President Obama says he wants to know “whose ass to kick” over the Gulf oil spill. In an interview with NBC’s Today show, the president said he would have fired BP CEO Tony Hayward “by now” over the company’s handling of the spill. “If I were Tony Hayward, I would be very angry,” Obama said. “I want to know who is responsible for this, and I want to know how much oil is being spilled.” Obama will visit Mississippi, Alabama, and Florida next week to view efforts to contain the spill. Meanwhile, BP said it was capturing more oil from its ruptured Gulf of Mexico well while the US Coast Guard tried to figure out just how much crude was still pouring out. Coast Guard Admiral Thad Allen, who leads the government's relief effort, said BP hoped to collect 20,000 barrels—or 840,000 gallons—per day in its latest effort to contain the worst spill in US history, which has now affected 120 miles of coastline. The figure underscored some scientists' concerns that the May 27 government estimate of up to 19,000 barrels coming daily from the well a mile under the sea may be too low. BP had estimated the flow at just 5,000 barrels a day.

– As the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico threatens to become one of the biggest environmental disasters in US history, BP is trying to boost its online presence. The company has bought the rights to certain search terms, including "oil spill" and "volunteer," to help direct Internet users to its website, reports the Financial Times. President Obama has criticized the company for spending $50 million on TV advertising to shore up its image, but BP says it's just trying to make it easier for people trying to access information on its website to find it.

– Scientists working on the Gulf oil spill released an updated estimate today of the amount of oil being spilled, and it’s looking a lot worse than thought. The best guess is that between 35,000 and 60,000 barrels are leaking daily, up from the last estimate of 20,000 to 40,000 barrels, reports the Washington Post. That’s a “significant step forward,” said Energy Secretary Steven Chu, calling it “a significant step forward. This estimate brings together several scientific methodologies and the latest information from the sea floor, and represents a significant step forward in our effort to put a number on the oil that is escaping from BP’s well.”

– One of New Orleans’ most prominent chefs is suing BP for damages because of the Gulf oil spill. Susan Spicer, who runs the Bayona restaurant in the French Quarter, is seeking class-action status for her lawsuit on behalf of restaurants and others in the seafood industry, which has suffered because of the spill, the Times-Picayune reports. BP spent another 300 million on the Gulf spill response in the past three days, bringing its total to 2.65 billion so far, according to the company’s statement. Meanwhile, the progress of BP’s relief wells is going more quickly than expected and the company could stop the flow of oil in mid-July, reports the British newspaper the Sunday Times.

– BP's latest plan to plug the gushing oil well is to pump mud into it, a strategy that has so far only succeeded in sucking about 900 barrels of oil a day from the Gulf of Mexico. That's less than half of what the company had hoped to suck up in a day, the Wall Street Journal reports, citing the head of BP's Gulf Coast restoration unit. The plan to pump mud into the well is a "worst-case scenario" one that will take at least a day, the head of BP's operations in the Gulf tells the New York Times. "We're not going to be able to stop the flow of oil on our own," he says. "We're going to have to deal with the uncontrolled flow of oil. We're not going to be able to do that."

– The blowout preventer that failed to stop the Deepwater Horizon oil spill had a dead battery, leaks in its hydraulic system, and a useless test version, according to a House investigation. Rep. Bart Stupak, chair of the House Energy and Commerce Committee's subcommittee on oversight, said today that documents and interviews show that the device was anything but, the Washington Post reports. BP's Lamar McKay, who visited Capitol Hill yesterday, said the company's operating management system in the Gulf of Mexico is "as good as anyone." But the panel's investigation found that the blowout preventer was made by Cameron, and that Transocean, the owner of the rig, was responsible for its design. Click here for more.

That's the distance between BP's latest attempt to contain the oil spill and the one-mile-deep leak that has been leaking since the Deepwater Horizon rig exploded two weeks ago, reports the Washington Post. Robotic submarines yesterday saw off the pipe that was leaking and installed a shutoff valve, but BP says that won't do much to reduce the amount of oil being spilled. "We feel great about sealing that leak," a BP spokesman told the Los Angeles Times. "But it's not going to significantly reduce the amount of oil being spilled."

– Coast Guard Adm. Thad Allen will continue to serve as President Obama's point man on the Gulf oil spill after he retires this month, the administration said yesterday. Obama tapped Allen last month to be national incident commander when he labeled the spill an "incident of national significance." Such incidents—usually a natural disaster or terrorist attack—require the president to appoint a federal official to coordinate the government's response. Allen is set to be relieved of his other duties by the end of May, but Homeland Security Secretary Janet Napolitano said yesterday that he will continue to serve as national incident commander. – BP's latest attempt to contain the oil spilling in the Gulf of Mexico failed today, as a blowout preventer failed to work, reports the Washington Post. The company tried pumping mud into the gushing well, but it didn't work. Interior Secretary Ken Salazar visited BP's US headquarters in Houston yesterday and said he was "frustrated" that the company hadn't been able to seal the well. "We are 33 days into this effort, and deadline after deadline has been missed," he said. "If we find they're not doing what they're supposed to be doing, we'll push them out of the way appropriately."

– BP's "top kill" operation is under way, and the company's chief executive says it will be 24 hours before they know whether it worked, reports the Los Angeles Times. The live operation involves pumping mud into the gushing well, but it's not clear whether it will do the trick. The best-case scenario is that it works, but it's not clear whether that will be enough to stop the oil, notes the New York Times. It's "far from a sure bet," says the newspaper's graphics team, which predicts that it will take at least a day to know for sure. Click here for more on the operation.

– BP's latest attempt to plug its gushing oil well in the Gulf of Mexico didn't work out so well, and the Obama administration is taking the unusual step of urging the company to take full responsibility for the health consequences of the spill, reports the Washington Post. Kathleen Sebelius told BP's chairman in a letter that the government is "very concerned about the impact of disaster on the public health of people in the Gulf region," and that the CDC is monitoring poison centers and other reporting systems for signs of possible health problems among cleanup workers and Gulf residents.

– The White House has ordered BP to pay for the cleanup of the Gulf oil spill, and the company has agreed, reports the New Orleans Times-Picayune. The White House also ordered BP to pay for the construction of five more large sections of Louisiana barrier island sand berms. BP has so far spent an estimated 360 million on cleanup efforts, but that's double what it has spent so far, notes the Wall Street Journal. The company has also hired the bipartisan corporate communications firm Purple Strategies, led by former Bush strategist Alex Castellanos and Democratic media consultant Steve McMahon, to help burnish its image.

– The oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico may be the worst environmental disaster in US history, but it's far from the first. The Indian Ocean tsunami in 2004, Hurricane Katrina in 2005, and the financial crisis in Greece in 2008 all occurred while the US was woefully unprepared for them, writes David Frum in the Washington Post. "Why are we so ill prepared for these disasters?" he asks. "God spoke to Moses through a burning bush on Mount Horeb. He apparently speaks to Republicans through a spewing oil well at the bottom of the Gulf of Mexico." Click here for Frum's full column.

– The US has accepted no offers of state-of-the-art oil-skimming equipment or miles of boom from other countries in the wake of the BP oil spill, the Washington Post reports. Instead, the US is soliciting offers from nearly two dozen countries and international organizations. “Here is the hard truth: The US government does not possess a secret method for capping oil leaks,” writes Glenn Greenwald. “Yes, the BP oil spill is Obama’s Katrina in the Gulf of Mexico, howling winds gathered and swooped down on the coast, ruining homes and destroying levees and flooding the city of New Orleans. It was an ecological disaster. It was an economic nightmare. And there was absolutely nothing the American president could do about it.”
